name: BitConnect
summary: Promised 1% daily returns through a 'trading bot'. Classic Ponzi scheme that collapsed in January 2018.
howItWorked: BitConnect operated a lending platform where users would lock up Bitcoin in exchange for BitConnect Coin (BCC). The platform claimed to use a proprietary 'trading bot' and 'volatility software' to generate guaranteed daily returns of up to 1%. In reality, returns were paid from new investor deposits — a textbook Ponzi scheme. The platform also had a multi-level referral system that incentivized recruitment, adding MLM characteristics to the fraud.

timeline.event: BitConnect launched as a cryptocurrency lending platform
BCC token listed on exchanges, begins rapid price increase
BCC reaches all-time high market cap of $2.6 billion
Ethereum founder Vitalik Buterin publicly calls BitConnect a Ponzi scheme
Texas State Securities Board issues cease and desist order
North Carolina issues cease and desist order
BitConnect announces closure of lending platform; BCC crashes 92%
DOJ charges promoter Glenn Arcaro with fraud; he pleads guilty
Founder Satish Kumbhani indicted by DOJ on fraud conspiracy charges
Glenn Arcaro sentenced to 38 months in prison

name: OneCoin
summary: Fake cryptocurrency with no real blockchain. Founder Ruja Ignatova disappeared and is on FBI's Most Wanted list.
howItWorked: OneCoin was marketed as a cryptocurrency but had no actual blockchain or mining infrastructure. Instead, it operated as a multi-level marketing scheme where participants bought educational packages that came with tokens they could use to 'mine' OneCoins. The coin's value was set internally by the company rather than by any market. Ruja Ignatova, known as the 'Cryptoqueen', held lavish events worldwide to recruit investors. The operation spanned 175+ countries and generated billions before collapsing.

timeline.event: OneCoin founded by Ruja Ignatova and Karl Sebastian Greenwood in Bulgaria
OneCoin reaches peak recruitment, holding global events with thousands of attendees
Ruja Ignatova disappears and has not been seen since
Her brother Konstantin Ignatov takes over leadership
Konstantin Ignatov arrested at LAX airport
Ruja Ignatova added to FBI's Ten Most Wanted Fugitives list
Europol adds Ignatova to Most Wanted list
Karl Sebastian Greenwood sentenced to 20 years in prison

name: Squid Game Token
summary: Exploited the Squid Game TV show hype. Token had a sell restriction — holders couldn't sell. Devs dumped everything.
howItWorked: Anonymous developers created the SQUID token capitalizing on the Netflix show's popularity. The token's smart contract contained an 'anti-dump' mechanism that prevented anyone except the creators from selling. As hype drove the price up over 23,000,000% in days, the developers dumped their holdings, crashing the price to near zero in minutes. This was a classic rug pull with a built-in exit scam mechanism.

timeline.event: SQUID token launches, marketed as play-to-earn game token
CNBC and other major outlets report on the token's massive gains
Reports emerge that holders cannot sell their tokens
Token reaches $2,861 per coin, then crashes to $0 in 5 minutes as devs dump
Project website and social media accounts deleted

name: Frosties NFT
summary: NFT project that rug-pulled hours after selling out. Founders arrested and charged with wire fraud.
howItWorked: Frosties was an Ethereum NFT collection of 8,888 ice cream-themed characters. The creators promised holders access to a metaverse game, rewards, and exclusive merchandise. Hours after the mint sold out for 0.04 ETH each, the developers drained the funds, shut down the Discord, and deleted social media. This was one of the first NFT rug pulls to result in criminal charges.

timeline.event: Frosties NFT project announced with roadmap promises
Collection sells out, raising ~$1.3 million in ETH
Hours later: Discord deleted, Twitter wiped, funds drained
Ethan Nguyen and Andre Llacuna arrested and charged with wire fraud and money laundering
Both defendants plead guilty

evidence.title: The Verge: First NFT Rug Pull Arrests

name: SafeMoon
summary: Marketed as a safe DeFi token. SEC charged founders with fraud, citing misuse of investor funds for personal luxury purchases.
howItWorked: SafeMoon launched as a BEP-20 token on the Binance Smart Chain with a 10% transaction fee — 5% redistributed to holders, 5% added to a liquidity pool. The team marketed this as an innovative 'tokenomics' model. In reality, founders secretly drained millions from the liquidity pool for personal use, including luxury cars, homes, and other purchases. The project was promoted heavily by influencers and social media campaigns.

timeline.event: SafeMoon token launches on Binance Smart Chain
Token gains massive following, endorsed by celebrities and influencers
SafeMoon reaches peak market cap of ~$6 billion
Coffeezilla publishes investigation showing liquidity pool drains
SafeMoon CEO John Karony fires CTO Thomas Smith
SEC charges SafeMoon, CEO Karony, CTO Smith, and CEO Braden John with fraud
John Karony arrested and charged with securities fraud and money laundering

name: Terra/LUNA
summary: Algorithmic stablecoin UST lost its peg, triggering a death spiral that wiped out LUNA and UST holders.
howItWorked: Terra was a blockchain ecosystem built around UST, an algorithmic stablecoin pegged to the US dollar. Instead of being backed by reserves, UST maintained its peg through a mint-and-burn mechanism with the LUNA token. When large withdrawals from the Anchor Protocol (which offered 20% APY on UST deposits) triggered UST to lose its peg, the algorithm minted trillions of LUNA tokens trying to restore it, creating a hyperinflationary death spiral. Both tokens collapsed to near zero within days.

timeline.event: Terraform Labs founded by Do Kwon and Daniel Shin
Anchor Protocol launches offering ~20% APY on UST deposits
UST becomes third-largest stablecoin with $18B market cap
Large UST withdrawals begin destabilizing the peg
UST depegs, falling to $0.35; LUNA crashes from $80 to under $1
Terra blockchain halted; LUNA and UST effectively worthless
Do Kwon arrested in Montenegro with fake passport
SEC charges Terraform Labs and Do Kwon with fraud
Terraform Labs found liable for fraud by jury

name: FTX
summary: Major crypto exchange collapsed after revelations of customer fund misuse. Founder SBF convicted of fraud.
howItWorked: FTX, run by Sam Bankman-Fried (SBF), was one of the world's largest cryptocurrency exchanges. Behind the scenes, FTX funneled billions in customer deposits to its sister trading firm Alameda Research, which used the funds for risky trades, venture investments, political donations, and personal expenses. When a CoinDesk report revealed Alameda's balance sheet was largely backed by FTX's own FTT token, a bank run ensued. FTX couldn't cover withdrawals and filed for bankruptcy within days.

timeline.event: FTX exchange founded by Sam Bankman-Fried
FTX raises $900M at $18B valuation
FTX valued at $32 billion after $400M raise
FTX runs Super Bowl ad featuring Larry David
CoinDesk publishes Alameda balance sheet showing FTT dependency
Binance CEO CZ announces selling all FTT holdings
FTX halts customer withdrawals
FTX files for bankruptcy; SBF resigns as CEO
SBF arrested in Bahamas
SBF found guilty on all 7 criminal counts
SBF sentenced to 25 years in prison

name: Celsius Network
summary: Crypto lending platform froze withdrawals and filed bankruptcy. CEO charged with fraud.
howItWorked: Celsius offered high-yield interest accounts for crypto deposits, promising returns up to 18% APY. The platform claimed to generate these returns through institutional lending and DeFi strategies. In reality, Celsius was taking excessive risks with customer deposits, including making undercollateralized loans and speculative DeFi plays. CEO Alex Mashinsky also allegedly manipulated the CEL token price. When the crypto market crashed in 2022, Celsius couldn't cover its liabilities and froze all customer withdrawals.

timeline.event: Celsius Network founded by Alex Mashinsky
Celsius reaches $25 billion in assets under management
Celsius raises $750M at $3.25B valuation
Celsius pauses all withdrawals, swaps, and transfers
Celsius files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy
Alex Mashinsky arrested and charged with fraud
Mashinsky pleads guilty to commodities fraud and market manipulation

name: Bored Bunny NFT
summary: Celebrity-promoted NFT project that promised utility and metaverse integration. Delivered nothing after sellout.
howItWorked: Bored Bunny was an NFT collection promoted by celebrities including Floyd Mayweather, DJ Khaled, and Jake Paul. The project promised staking rewards, a metaverse game, merchandise, and charity donations. After minting sold out for ~$20 million, the team delivered none of the promised roadmap items. Celebrity promoters failed to disclose their paid partnerships, and the project's value plummeted to near zero.

timeline.event: Bored Bunny announced with celebrity promotion campaign
Multiple celebrities promote the project on social media
Collection mints out, raising approximately $20 million
No roadmap items delivered; community grows frustrated
Floor price drops over 95% from mint price
SEC signals investigations into celebrity NFT promotions

evidence.title: SEC Charges Celebrities for NFT Promos

name: Save The Kids Token
summary: Promoted by FaZe Clan members as a charity token. Insiders dumped immediately after launch.
howItWorked: Save The Kids was marketed as a charitable cryptocurrency endorsed by members of FaZe Clan, including FaZe Kay, FaZe Jarvis, and others. The token claimed that a portion of transaction fees would go to charity. However, the smart contract was modified before launch to remove anti-dump protections, allowing insiders to sell immediately while regular buyers were restricted. Promoters dumped their tokens shortly after launch, crashing the price.

timeline.event: Save The Kids token announced with FaZe Clan member endorsements
Token launches; insiders dump within hours
Token price crashes over 90%
Coffeezilla publishes investigation exposing the scheme
FaZe Clan suspends members Kay, Jarvis, Nikan, and Teeqo

name: Mutant Ape Planet
summary: NFT collection mimicking BAYC. Creator arrested for wire fraud after rug-pulling buyers.
howItWorked: Mutant Ape Planet was an NFT collection designed to look like Bored Ape Yacht Club derivatives. The creator, Aurelien Michel, promised holders exclusive access to token airdrops, merch, metaverse land, and a DAO. After selling out the collection for ~$2.9 million, Michel attempted to drain the funds. Community members initially prevented the rug pull through social pressure, but Michel eventually fled with the money. He was later arrested at JFK airport.

timeline.event: Mutant Ape Planet NFT collection announced
Collection sells out for approximately 2.9 million dollars
Creator attempts to drain funds; community confronts him on Discord
Creator admits to rug pull on Discord: 'rug pulled, deal with it'
Aurelien Michel arrested at JFK Airport
Michel pleads guilty to wire fraud conspiracy

name: Voyager Digital
summary: Crypto broker filed for bankruptcy after Three Arrows Capital default. Customer funds frozen.
howItWorked: Voyager Digital was a publicly traded crypto brokerage offering high-yield interest accounts. The platform lent customer assets to institutional borrowers, including Three Arrows Capital (3AC). When 3AC defaulted on a $650 million loan, Voyager couldn't cover the shortfall. Despite CEO Steve Ehrlich's assurances that customer funds were safe and FDIC-insured (they weren't), Voyager froze withdrawals and filed for bankruptcy.

timeline.event: Voyager Digital founded as a crypto brokerage
Voyager goes public on Toronto Stock Exchange
Three Arrows Capital defaults on $650M loan from Voyager
Voyager freezes customer withdrawals
Voyager files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy
FTC charges Voyager and CEO with making false FDIC insurance claims
Voyager settles with FTC; Ehrlich banned from handling customer assets

name: Axie Infinity Ronin Hack
summary: North Korean hackers (Lazarus Group) exploited the Ronin bridge, stealing ETH and USDC.
howItWorked: The Ronin Network was a sidechain built by Sky Mavis for their play-to-earn game Axie Infinity. It used a proof-of-authority consensus with only 9 validators. The Lazarus Group, a North Korean state-sponsored hacking group, compromised 5 of the 9 validator private keys through a fake job offer phishing attack targeting a Sky Mavis engineer. With majority control of validators, they drained 173,600 ETH and 25.5M USDC from the Ronin bridge. The hack went undetected for 6 days.

timeline.event: Lazarus Group executes the Ronin bridge exploit, stealing $620M
Hack discovered after a user fails to withdraw funds
Ronin bridge shut down; Sky Mavis discloses the breach
FBI and Treasury attribute hack to North Korea's Lazarus Group
Sky Mavis raises $150M to reimburse affected users
Authorities recover $30M of the stolen funds

name: Pixelmon NFT
summary: Raised $70M promising AAA-quality game NFTs. Revealed artwork was laughably bad. Community outraged.
howItWorked: Pixelmon promised a AAA-quality open-world game featuring collectible NFT creatures. The project generated massive hype, with mints priced at 3 ETH (~$9,000 at the time). The team raised approximately $70 million. When the actual NFT artwork was revealed, it was comically terrible — pixelated, deformed creatures that looked nothing like the promotional art. The most infamous was 'Kevin,' a poorly rendered zombie-like creature that became a meme. Despite the quality disaster, the team kept the funds.

timeline.event: Pixelmon announced with AAA-quality game promises and promotional art
NFTs mint for 3 ETH each, raising ~$70 million
NFT artwork revealed: comically bad quality, 'Kevin' meme goes viral
Floor price crashes from 3 ETH to 0.3 ETH
Founder admits most funds spent on marketing, not development
Project attempts rebrand and recovery under new leadership

name: Wonderland (TIME)
summary: DeFi protocol's treasury manager revealed to be QuadrigaCX co-founder, a convicted fraudster.
howItWorked: Wonderland was an OHM-fork DeFi protocol on Avalanche that managed a large community treasury. The project promised high yields through strategic treasury management. In January 2022, it was revealed that the protocol's treasury manager, '0xSifu,' was actually Michael Patryn (aka Omar Dhanani) — the co-founder of the collapsed Canadian exchange QuadrigaCX and a convicted financial criminal. Despite this revelation, Wonderland's pseudonymous founder 'Daniele Sestagalli' initially defended keeping Patryn on, causing massive community backlash and withdrawals.

timeline.event: Wonderland launches as an OHM-fork on Avalanche
TIME token reaches all-time high; treasury grows to $1B+
Blockchain sleuth ZachXBT reveals 0xSifu's real identity as Michael Patryn
Daniele Sestagalli initially defends keeping Patryn
Mass withdrawals begin; TIME price collapses
Community votes to wind down the protocol

name: Thodex
summary: Turkish crypto exchange CEO fled with customer funds. Eventually caught and sentenced to 11,196 years.
howItWorked: Thodex was one of Turkey's largest cryptocurrency exchanges, serving over 700,000 users. Founder Faruk Fatih Ozer lured users with promotional campaigns offering free Dogecoin. On April 20, 2021, Ozer suddenly halted trading and fled Turkey on a private plane to Albania. Users found they could no longer access their funds. Ozer remained a fugitive for over a year before being caught in Albania and extradited to Turkey.

timeline.event: Thodex exchange launched in Turkey
Thodex runs Dogecoin giveaway campaign to attract new users
Trading halted; Ozer flees Turkey to Albania
Turkish prosecutors launch investigation; Interpol red notice issued
Faruk Fatih Ozer arrested in Albania
Ozer extradited to Turkey
Ozer sentenced to 11,196 years in prison

name: PlusToken
summary: Chinese Ponzi scheme disguised as a crypto wallet. Promised high returns for staking.
howItWorked: PlusToken was marketed as a cryptocurrency wallet and exchange, primarily in China and South Korea. It promised users monthly returns of 10-30% through 'AI-powered arbitrage trading.' Users deposited Bitcoin, Ethereum, and other cryptocurrencies. The scheme attracted millions of users across Asia. In reality, returns were paid from new deposits. When the operators couldn't sustain payments, they executed an exit scam, moving billions in crypto through complex laundering chains.

timeline.event: PlusToken launches as a crypto wallet and exchange
PlusToken claims 10 million users
PlusToken stops paying returns; users can't withdraw
Six suspects arrested in Vanuatu by Chinese police
Chinese authorities seize $4.2 billion in crypto assets
109 people charged; leaders sentenced to up to 11 years in prison

name: IcomTech
summary: Targeted Latino communities with crypto mining scam. CEO sentenced to 5 years in prison.
howItWorked: IcomTech targeted Spanish-speaking communities, particularly in the Dominican Republic, Colombia, and Latino communities in the US. The company claimed to operate cryptocurrency mining facilities and promised investors daily returns of 0.5-2%. IcomTech held flashy events at luxury venues, showing off expensive cars and jewelry to lure investors. In reality, the company never operated mining equipment at any meaningful scale and used new investor money to pay existing investors.

timeline.event: IcomTech begins operations, targeting Latino communities
IcomTech holds recruitment events in luxury venues across Latin America
Platform stops paying returns; investors unable to withdraw
Company goes silent; website taken offline
CEO David Carmona arrested and charged with wire fraud
Carmona sentenced to 5 years in federal prison

name: CryptoZoo
summary: Logan Paul's NFT game project exposed by Coffeezilla. Promised game never delivered despite millions raised.
howItWorked: CryptoZoo was promoted by Logan Paul as a play-to-earn game where users could buy NFT eggs, hatch them into animals, and breed them to earn ZOO tokens. Users spent millions buying Base Eggs and ZOO tokens on the promise of a functioning game. The game was never completed — users could buy and hatch eggs, but the breeding and earning mechanics were never implemented. Coffeezilla's three-part investigation revealed a pattern of broken promises, finger-pointing between team members, and no accountability for the missing funds.

timeline.event: Logan Paul announces CryptoZoo project
ZOO token launches; Base Eggs go on sale
Egg hatching goes live, but breeding mechanics are absent
Community grows frustrated as game development stalls
Coffeezilla publishes three-part investigation
Logan Paul promises to buy back eggs and reimburse investors
Logan Paul sues Coffeezilla (later drops lawsuit)
Partial refund program launched but many investors remain uncompensated

name: MetaMask Phishing Attacks
summary: Fake MetaMask sites and email campaigns tricking users into entering seed phrases. Ongoing threat.
howItWorked: Attackers create convincing replicas of the MetaMask website, browser extension pages, and support emails. Common tactics include: phishing emails claiming wallet issues requiring 'verification,' fake Google ads for 'MetaMask Download' that lead to cloned sites, fraudulent browser extensions that steal seed phrases, and social engineering through fake support channels. Once victims enter their seed phrase or private key, attackers immediately drain all assets from the wallet.

timeline.event: First major MetaMask phishing campaigns detected
Google Ads phishing campaign reaches mainstream users
MetaMask issues official warning about phishing through iCloud backups
Address poisoning attacks become widespread
MetaMask introduces phishing detection features
Phishing attacks continue with increasingly sophisticated methods
